case_name: Istimrardar of Kharwa v. State of Ajmer

facts.text: This is a Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1954 under Article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1954. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

facts.text: The appeal is from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd November 1952 of the Judicial Commissioners Court, Ajmer, in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd November 1952 of the Judicial Commissioners Court, Ajmer, in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1952.

facts.text: The appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa.

anchor.surface_text: BOSe J.-The appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa. According to him, be has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.

facts.text: The appellant has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, be has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years. On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer.

facts.text: On 8-1-1951, the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877.

anchor.surface_text: On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer. He purported to do this under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877  Reg. III of 1877 .

facts.text: One of the rules required persons desiring to hold fairs to obtain a permit from the District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: One of the rules required that persons desiring to hold fairs should obtain a permit from the District Magistrate. Accordingly the appellant applied for a permit.

facts.text: The appellant applied for a permit to hold the fair.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the appellant applied for a permit. This was refused on the ground that numbermore permits were to be issued to private individuals.

facts.text: The permit was refused on the ground that no more permits were to be issued to private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: This was refused on the ground that numbermore permits were to be issued to private individuals. The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer

facts.text: The appellant applied under article 226 to the Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer for a writ directing authorities to permit holding the fair.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer for the issue of a writ directing the authorities companycerned to permit the appellant to hold his fair as usual.

facts.text: The Judicial Commissioner refused to issue the writ but granted leave to appeal under article 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner refused to issue the writ but granted leave to appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution in the following terms I am of opinion that the question whether the regulation and the bye-laws framed thereunder amount to a reasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental right to hold a cattle fair in his own land involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

facts.text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is numbermally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1  f  which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause  5 .

facts.text: The appellant applied for a permit on 9-7-1952.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant applied for a permit on 9-7-1952  the District Magistrate replied It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and number to private individuals.

facts.text: The District Magistrate replied that permits would be issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: the District Magistrate replied It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and number to private individuals. It is, therefore, regretted that you cannot be permitted to hold the fair and you are therefore requested to please abandon the idea.

facts.text: The District Magistrate's order declining the permit is dated 18th September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts because the point on which we have proceeded was number taken in proper time in this Court.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on December 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and P. G. Gokhale for the respondents. 1954. December 3. The judgment of Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J., Mukherjea, Vivian Bose, Bhagwati and Venkatarama Ayyar JJ. was delivered by Bose J.

facts.text: The District Magistrate declined to grant a permit on 18th September 1952 on the ground that permits are issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: JAGANNADHADAS J.-The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and number to private individuals is bad for two reasons.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: C. Chatterji, I. N. Shroff.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterji  I. N. Shroff, with him  for the appellant. Porus A. Mehta and P. G. Gokhale for the respondents. 1954. December 3.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents: Porus A. Mehta and P. G. Gokhale.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and P. G. Gokhale for the respondents. 1954. December 3. The judgment of Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J., Mukherjea, Vivian Bose, Bhagwati and Venkatarama Ayyar JJ. was delivered by Bose J.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by Bose J. for Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J., Mukherjea, Vivian Bose, Bhagwati and Venkatarama Ayyar JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J., Mukherjea, Vivian Bose, Bhagwati and Venkatarama Ayyar JJ. was delivered by Bose J. The judgment of Das and Jagannadhadas JJ. was delivered by Jagannadhadas J.

facts.text: Separate judgment delivered by Jagannadhadas J. for Das and Jagannadhadas JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of Das and Jagannadhadas JJ. was delivered by Jagannadhadas J. BOSE J.-The appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa. According to him, be has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1954. Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd November 1952 of the Judicial Commissioners Court, Ajmer, in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1952. C. Chatterji

concepts.unlisted_description: Appeal to Supreme Court on substantial question of constitutional interpretation

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner refused to issue the writ but granted leave to appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution in the following terms I am of opinion that the question whether the regulation and the bye-laws framed thereunder amount to a reasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental right to hold a cattle fair in his own land involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer for the issue of a writ directing the authorities companycerned to permit the appellant to hold his fair as usual. He companytended that his fundamental rights under the Constitution were infringed and also that the rules promulgated by the Chief Commissioner were ultra vires the Regulation under which he purported to act.

concepts.interpretation: High Court writ jurisdiction invoked for directing authorities to permit holding the fair

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ising or carrying on the occupation or business in question.  Article 19 6  as amended in 1951 . The only law relevant here is sec

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is numbermally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1  f  which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause  5 . The holding of an annual fair is an occupation or business within the meaning of article 19  1   g , therefore, the appellant also has a fundamental right to engage in that occupation on his land provided it does number infringe any law imposing reasonable restrictions on that right in the interests of the general public, or any law relating to- the professional or technical qualifications necessary for practising or carrying on the occupation or business in question.  Article 19 6  as amended in 1951 .

concepts.interpretation: Fundamental right under Art 19(1)(f) to hold fair on own land and under Art 19(1)(g) to carry on occupation of holding annual fair, restrictable only by reasonable restrictions under Art 19(5)/(6)

anchor.surface_text: On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer. He purported to do this under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877  Reg. III of 1877 . One of the rules required that persons desiring to hold fairs should obtain a permit from the District Magistrate. Accordingly the appellant applied for a permit. This was refused on the ground that numbermore permits were to be issued to private individuals. The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer for the issue of a writ directing the authorities companycerned to permit the appellant to hold his fair as usual.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Chief Commissioner to make rules for maintenance of watch and ward, establishment of proper system of conservancy and sanitation at fairs, imposition of taxes therefor, and registration of cattle

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: two hundred rupees, or both. These sections were number impugned in the argument before us number were they attacked in the petition made to the Judic

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule-making power for sanitation, watch and ward, taxes, cattle registration at fairs

anchor.surface_text: Under section 40, the Chief Commissioner is empowered, among other things, to make rules about- 1068  a  the maintenance of watch and ward, and the establishment of a proper system of companyservancy and sanitation at fairs and other large public assemblies  b  the imposition of taxes for the purposes mentioned in clause  a  of this section on persons holding or joining any of the assemblies therein referred to  b  the registration of cattle. Section 41 provides for penalties in the following terms The Chief Commissioner may, in making any rule under this Regulation, attach to the breach of it, in addition to any other companysequences that would entire from such breach, a punishment, on companyviction before a Magistrate, number exceeding rigorous or simple imprisonment for a month or a fine of two hundred rupees, or both.

concepts.interpretation: Authorizes attachment of penalties to rules made under the Regulation, up to one month imprisonment or Rs 200 fine

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rict Magistrate replied It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and number to private

concepts.unlisted_description: Penalty provisions for breach of rules

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation companyfers this power on the Chief Commissioner and number on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

concepts.interpretation: Delegation by Chief Commissioner to District Magistrate to determine proper system of conservancy etc. exceeds power conferred on Chief Commissioner by Regulation

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: gistrate is ultra vires. Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke a permit granted without assignin

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous numberice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

concepts.interpretation: Empowerment of District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice is absolute arbitrary power beyond Regulation

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rules, they are, so far as the Regulation is companycerned, entitled to hold their fair, for there is numberother law restricting that right. Therefo

concepts.unlisted_description: Acting beyond legal authority conferred by parent enactment

anchor.surface_text: As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad for, without the aid of these rules or of some other law validly 1070 empowering him to impose the ban, he has numberpower in himself to do it. The matter is companyered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 . The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952.

concepts.interpretation: Rules void to extent ultra vires; District Magistrate's prohibitory order quashed for lack of valid empowering provision

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are number within the ambit of the rule-making power. These r

concepts.unlisted_description: Acting beyond legal authority conferred by parent enactment

anchor.surface_text: JAGANNADHADAS J.-The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and number to private individuals is bad for two reasons. The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and companyditions as he may deem fit. But they do number authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done. The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are number within the ambit of the rule-making power.

concepts.interpretation: Rules establishing permit system and ad hoc control by DM do not constitute a 'proper system of conservancy and sanitation' under S.40 but exceed rule-making power; refusal on policy ground (only local bodies) unauthorized by rules
concepts.unlisted_description: Subordinate legislation not within scope or intent of enabling provision

issues.text: Whether the regulation and the bye-laws framed thereunder amount to a reasonable restriction on the appellant's fundamental right to hold a cattle fair in his own land

anchor.surface_text: I am of opinion that the question whether the regulation and the bye-laws framed thereunder amount to a reasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental right to hold a cattle fair in his own land involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the rules promulgated by the Chief Commissioner are ultra vires the Regulation under which he purported to act

anchor.surface_text: He contended that his fundamental rights under the Constitution were infringed and also that the rules promulgated by the Chief Commissioner were ultra vires the Regulation under which he purported to act.

issues.text: Whether the rules empower the District Magistrate to determine what a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward is, and whether such delegation by the Chief Commissioner is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation confers this power on the Chief Commissioner and not on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the fourth sub-rule of Rule I empowering the District Magistrate to revoke any permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous notice is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous notice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate is authorised by the rules to refuse a permit on the ground that permits are to be issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals

anchor.surface_text: The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and not to private individuals is bad for two reasons. The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and conditions as he may deem fit. But they do not authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

issues.text: Whether the rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for are within the ambit of the rule-making power under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation
Whether the impugned order infringes the appellant's fundamental rights under article 19

arguments.claim: Chief Commissioner delegated authority to District Magistrate to determine proper system of conservancy etc., which is ultra vires as power conferred only on Chief Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation confers this power on the Chief Commissioner and number on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

arguments.claim: Fourth sub-rule empowering District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice grants absolute arbitrary power which is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous numberice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

arguments.claim: District Magistrate's order prohibiting fair is bad without valid rules empowering him

anchor.surface_text: As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad for, without the aid of these rules or of some other law validly 1070 empowering him to impose the ban, he has numberpower in himself to do it. The matter is companyered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 .

arguments.claim: Rules do not authorize District Magistrate to refuse permit on ground of policy to issue only to local bodies

anchor.surface_text: The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and number to private individuals is bad for two reasons. The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and companyditions as he may deem fit. But they do number authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

arguments.claim: Rules establishing permit system are not within rule-making power under ss.40-41 as they constitute ad hoc control, not a proper system of conservancy etc.

anchor.surface_text: The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are number within the ambit of the rule-making power. These rules purport to have been framed in exercise of the powers companyferred by sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877. Section 40 authorises the framing of the rules for the maintenance of watch and ward and the establishment of a proper system of companyservancy and sanitation at fairs and other large public assemblies.

holdings.text: the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation confers this power on the Chief Commissioner and not on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation empowers Chief Commissioner to establish and specify a proper system of conservancy etc. in rules, not to delegate determination to District Magistrate on ad hoc basis.

holdings.text: This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous notice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Empowering District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice confers uncontrolled arbitrary power exceeding rule-making authority under Regulation.

holdings.text: We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952.

anchor.surface_text: As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad for, without the aid of these rules or of some other law validly 1070 empowering him to impose the ban, he has no power in himself to do it. The matter is covered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 . The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-rules ultra vires lead to invalidity of rules to that extent and quashing of District Magistrate's prohibitory order lacking independent valid authority; supported by precedent.

holdings.text: The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and not to private individuals is bad for two reasons. ... But they do not authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

anchor.surface_text: JAGANNADHADAS J.-The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and not to private individuals is bad for two reasons. The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and conditions as he may deem fit. But they do not authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules authorize refusal only if applicant cannot ensure conservancy/sanitation/watch and ward, or to impose conditions; policy ground of preferring local bodies unauthorized.

holdings.text: The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are not within the ambit of the rule-making power.

anchor.surface_text: The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are not within the ambit of the rule-making power. These rules purport to have been framed in exercise of the powers conferred by sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877. Section 40 authorises the framing of the rules for the maintenance of watch and ward and the establishment of a proper system of conservancy and sanitation at fairs and other large public assemblies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit system creates ad hoc control by District Magistrate rather than establishing a definite 'proper system' of conservancy/sanitation/watch as required by s.40; exceeds enabling power.

holdings.text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19(1)(f) which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause (5). The holding of an annual fair is an occupation or business within the meaning of article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1 f  which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause  5 . The holding of an annual fair is an occupation or business within the meaning of article 19  1   g , therefore, the appellant also has a fundamental right to engage in that occupation on his land provided it does not infringe any law imposing reasonable restrictions on that right in the interests of the general public, or any law relating to- the professional or technical qualifications necessary for practising or carrying on the occupation or business in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ownership of land gives right under Art.19(1)(f); holding annual fair qualifies as occupation/business under Art.19(1)(g), restrictable only reasonably under cl.(5)/(6).

holdings.text: this is enough to dispose of the appeal and it is not necessary to express any opinion as to whether the impugned order infringes also the appellants fundamental rights under article 19.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order invalid on ultra vires grounds, rendering Art.19 issue academic/not necessary to decide.

edges.explanation: Fact of framing rules under sections 40 and 41 triggers issue of whether within rule-making power under those sections.

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation confers this power on the Chief Commissioner and not on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts becaus

Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous notice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts becaus

edges.explanation: Holding declares rules void, addressing the ultra vires issue.

anchor.surface_text: As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad for, without the aid of these rules or of some other law validly 1070 empowering him to impose the ban, he has no power in himself to do it. The matter is covered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 . The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952.

JAGANNADHADAS J.-The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and not to private individuals is bad for two reasons. The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and conditions as he may deem fit. But they do not authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts becaus
by the District Magistrate through the issue of a permit and by the vesting of other powers in him under the rules. These cannot be said to be rules w

anchor.surface_text: by the District Magistrate through the issue of a permit and by the vesting of other powers in him under the rules. These cannot be said to be rules w

anchor.surface_text: The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are not within the ambit of the rule-making power. These rules purport to have been framed in exercise of the powers conferred by sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877. Section 40 authorises the framing of the rules for the maintenance of watch and ward and the establishment of a proper system of conservancy and sanitation at fairs and other large public assemblies.

The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts becaus

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1 f  which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause  5 . The holding of an annual fair is an occupation or business within the meaning of article 19  1   g , therefore, the appellant also has a fundamental right to engage in that occupation on his land provided it does not infringe any law imposing reasonable restrictions on that right in the interests of the general public, or any law relating to- the professional or technical qualifications necessary for practising or carrying on the occupation or business in question.
